description: US approved HT alfalfa in 2005; later re-approved 2011 after litigation. Canada also approved.
US approved Arctic apple in 2015. Canada also approved.
Bangladesh: four BARI Bt brinjal varieties approved in 2013; cultivation began 2014 and expanded thereafter.
Approved by GEAC in 2009 but placed under moratorium in 2010; not cultivated.
Approved in 2002; multiple events cultivated widely.
Australia: first commercial GM canola releases in 2003 (Roundup Ready & InVigor).
Canada: first GM crop (1995); >90% adoption. US also grows HT canola.
GM canola not cultivated in EU but imports authorised.
South Africa: Bt cotton was the first GM crop commercialized in the country (late 1990s).
Nigeria: Bt cotton MRC 7377 BGII and MRC 7361 BGII commercialized; higher yields reported vs. conventional.
Paraguay: Bt cotton cultivated (commercial approvals noted in GAIN).
Mexico: GM cotton widely cultivated; production mainly domestic use with some exports.
Brazil approved Bt cotton in 2005 (Bollgard/event 531); later stacked HT+IR traits widely cultivated.
Australia: GM cotton cultivated since 1996; >99% of area uses GM traits.
GM cotton not cultivated in EU but imports are authorised for feed/food.
Nigeria: event AAT709A; reduces insecticide sprays and increases yield.
Philippines: commercial propagation permit issued Oct 18, 2022; release halted by CA in Apr 2024.
Brazil approved GM eucalyptus H421 in 2015, resistant to Lepidopteran pests.
Egypt: GM foods/feeds imported; cultivation banned (2012).
New Zealand: GM foods permitted after FSANZ safety assessment (Schedule 26).
GM maize varieties received safety clearance but not yet commercialised widely.
Approved by GEAC in 2022; cultivation contested by Supreme Court cases.
Rice with GM traits cleared for biosafety in 2009 but not commercialised.
Brazil has approved many maize events (e.g., MON810, Bt11, TC1507) and stacked traits; first approvals in the early 2000s.
Vietnam: GE corn hybrids approved for cultivation starting 2014 (exceptional recognition), resumed 2023; only GE crop cultivated.
South Africa: MON810 and later stacked traits widely cultivated.
Philippines: GE corn approved since 2002 and widely grown.
Mexico: extensive food/feed authorizations; cultivation of GM maize restricted/contested.
Only GM crop cultivated in the EU; grown mainly in Spain (also Portugal).
Nigeria: TELA maize (SAMMAZ 72T–75T) resistant to fall armyworm/stem borers and tolerant to drought.
US: Rainbow papaya approved 1998 in Hawaii.
US approved Innate potato in 2014; Canada also approved.
Philippines: commercial propagation permit issued July 2021; Court of Appeals revoked permit in Apr 2024.
Australia: first commercial GM safflower released in 2018 for industrial oil uses.
RR soybean approved 1996; Intacta RR2 PRO approved 2012 and adopted thereafter.
South Africa: Roundup Ready soybean (GTS 40-3-2) approved for cultivation in 2001; additional traits later.
US: RR soybean approved 1994; stacked HT+IR widely grown. Canada also approves RR soybean.
Brazil first approved Roundup Ready soybean (GTS 40-3-2) in 1998; Intacta RR2 PRO approved in 2010 with Bt insect resistance.
China is world’s largest importer of GM soybean.
Not cultivated in EU, but imported for feed & food use (multiple events approved).
US approved virus-resistant squash in 1995.
US approved HT sugar beet in 2005; widely grown. Canada also approves.
GM sugar beet not cultivated in EU but imports authorised.
Brazil approved GM sugarcane CTC91087-6 in 2017 for resistance to sugarcane borer.
